Gaby says that this time she is applying for a loan to buy corn and products like bread, eggs, milk, soft-drinks, sugar e.t.c To stock her grocery shop by making tortillas has already taken a year and the shop has been going for the same amount of time. Gaby said she wanted to start by making tortillas because she wanted to help her husband with the household expenses. 

Gaby said, 'I really like my work and more when there are profits, only at this time I haven't been doing so well considering that at the moment people have corn that they harvested at the end of the year. So right now I wont do well with the profits of tortilla sales, although it's only for a period because half-way through the year people find themselves with no corn and so start to buy tortillas. But I will work harder in the shop to make up for it regarding the profits.'

Gaby's goal is to gain more customers to increase her profits so she will be able to offer her children a better quality of life. Just like Gaby who has dreams, the other members of the group are applying for loans to invest in their businesses. Doña María will invest in the sale of tortillas and vegetables and Luis Enrique in the grocery store. They are very grateful for and happy with the support given by the institution and KIVA.

loans.use: to buy milk, eggs, sugar, bread, soft drinks, detergents.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius lives in Buyanja town in Lyantonde with his family and relatives. He owns a corn milling machine which he operates on a daily basis. He also buys and sells millet flour. He has a retail shop that his wife works in. He has four children aged 6, 4, 2 and 1. His oldest child has just started going to school.
Julius' plan for the loan he has requested is to pay school fees and to buy additional bags of cereal.

loans.use: to buy additional bags of cereal.

loans.name: Barbra's Group

texts.en:
Barbra's group is comprised of three hardworking women. Barbra is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka region of Uganda. For the past year, Barbra has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells soft drinks. 

To help expand her business, Barbra has requested a loan of 800000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drinks such as passion fruit for making juice and soda to sell, and will help Barbra to generate greater profits and take care of her family members by providing for all the basic needs. Barbra hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business and add some different soft drinks, such as all types of Splash. 

Barbra is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more drinks such as passion fruit for making juice and soda to sell.

loans.name: Bush House Group

texts.en:
Musu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Musu was born in 1954. She is a widow with five children, two of whom are attending primary schools. Musu sells palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), firewood, charcoal and other goods. 

With the help of this loan, Musu and her group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Musu will use her share of the loan (SLL 700,000) to buy palm oil, firewood and charcoal in large quantities to add to her business. 

(Also included on the right of the photo is loan officer Rosaline, posing with the clients).

loans.use: to buy palm oil, firewood and charcoal in large quantities to add to her business

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka region of Uganda. For the past three years, Agnes has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells maize flour, sugar, soap, and drinks. 

To help expand her business, Agnes has requested a loan of 700000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential commodities like milk, bread, sugar, and soap for resale, and will help Agnes to generate greater profits and take care of herself and her young brother. Agnes hopes that in the future she will be able to own a big whole sale shop in town. 

Agnes is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more essatial commodities like milk, bread, sugar, and soap to sell.

loans.name: Hafiswa's Group

texts.en:
Hafiswa's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Hafiswa is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka region of Uganda. For the past year, Hafiswa has been working hard to manage her market stall, which sells fresh vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Hafiswa has requested a loan of 600000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh vegetables to expand her business and generate greater profits, and to buy new clothes for herself. Hafiswa hopes that in the future she will be able to own a plot of land. 

Hafiswa is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh vegetables to expand her business.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 46 years old. He runs a general store whereby he sells assorted goods and cereals to his customers in Mishomuhoroni, Mombasa Kenya. He is a married man who supports three people in his family. He has been in this business for the past year and has done well. 

Robert is requesting a first loan to purchase more stock of dry cereals, sugar and cooking fat, and also to pay school fees for the children. 

He will use the anticipated profit to expand his general store and pay his loan. Robert hopes to succeed in the future.

loans.use: to purchase stock of dry cereals, sugar and cooking fat, and also to pay school fees.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex lives in Kisetuula with his family of six children and four dependents.  He and his wife and family survive on the bare minimum.

Alex buys and sells cereals to earn a living.  His wish is to reach the point in his life where he is able to afford all that he needs.  In his own words his dream is to become "rich.”

With this loan he wants to buy more cereals.

loans.use: To purchase more cereals.

loans.name: Kakhaber

texts.en:
Kakhaber is from the small town of Ozurgeti. He is 44 years old, married, and lives with his wife and two children (7 and 10 years old) who go to the local school. In fact, the family has no source of income as Kakhaber and his wife are unemployed at the moment. Kakhaber has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for starting a trading business, but has not had success. His loan requests have been rejected because of his low income and his lack of experience in his job, which is usually important criteria for the local credit providers. 

This loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provisions of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit Kakhaber will purchase flour and bran at wholesale prices and resell them for a profit. It will be hard work for Kakhaber, but according to estimations his business will be profitable and increase the income of the family. The increased profit will be reinvested in the trading business to increase his stock and volume of sales. The family members will be able to increase their spending to satisfy their daily needs in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase flour and bran for resale

loans.name: Gjelina

texts.en:
Gjelina is 43 years old and married with three children.  She is from northeastern Albania. 

The main activity for locals in such regions of Albania is livestock: selling milk, making cheese, cottage cheese, butter and yogurt. So does Gjelina, who has dairy cows and goats and produces cheese upon her clients’ requests. 

Gjelina has been doing this for the past six years and has been experiencing a need for her dairy products. This makes her happy. Locals said that she makes delicious cheese, so they prefer hers versus others.

Gjelina is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders to build a stable for the animals.

loans.use: to build a stable for her animals.

loans.name: Batkhorloo

texts.en:
Mr. Batkhorloo is 28 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in an apartment.  

His wife has been running a business, selling belts at a sales center by renting stalls for six years and has accumulated a vast amount of experience.  For the past year, he has been producing and selling vacuum insulated windows and, even though he has been in business for a short time, he has succeeded in attracting quite a number of permanent clients. 

The apartment they live in has deteriorated over the years and needs some serious repair.  So, he is requesting a loan of 6,700,000 MNT in order to purchase construction and insulation materials such as gypsum, glass cottons and pressed board as well as to install a floor heating system.  As a result, the family can live in a comfortable and warm place without worrying about the chilling winds and frosts. The insulated and renovated apartment offers many benefits including not loosing heat.

loans.use: to purchase construction and insulation materials

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is 28 years old, married to Edward and a mother of three children who are eight, six and three years old. She is a livestock trader and has been running the business for the past three years making a monthly income of KES 20,000.

She has borrowed a third loan of KES 50,000 from KADET LTD, which she intends to use to purchase more sheep for resale. 

The anticipated profit will be reinvested to boost her business. Her future dream is to improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy sheep to fatten and sell

loans.name: Lambert

texts.en:
Lambert lives in Kaliro "A" in Lyantonde. He has a wife and four children. Lambert has struggled through life by getting loans, which have helped him to build a school and rental houses. He also deals in the buying and selling of cereals.

Lambert would like to use this loan to improve his rental houses. If some money is left over, he will buy a bag or two of cereals. Lambert desires to get to the point where he no longer has to borrow money.

loans.use: To improve his rental houses

loans.name: Advan

texts.en:
Advan, 23, is a single man who lives in the southern part of Kosovo with his entire family. He is a very hard worker. He works in a car wash for a very low salary and also owns a business collecting paper packaging and selling the paper for recycling. Advan buys scrap paper from markets and sells it to companies who do recycling. He buys at a cheaper price and then sells for a higher price.

Advan has requested a loan for the first time to buy more scrap paper. The loan will help him to sell more scrap paper, to increase his profit and to secure his future. His goal is to save the money for his future; he hopes to get married in the near future. Advan wants to thank all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: To buy more scrap paper

loans.name: Upendo Group

texts.en:
Felix’s group consists of 17 farmers (4 men and 13 women) located in Bungoma South District. Felix is pictured at the right of the photo with his hand raised. He will receive input loans to enable him to plant ½ an acre with millet, sorghum and maize. Felix joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Felix joined One Acre Fund so that he could access the best input prices and use his increased profits to send his children to school.

Felix described his last year's harvest as  poor, but believes he can have a better one this year. He hopes that his profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to repair his home and to invest in livestock. Felix’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ an acre during the 2013 Long Rains season, for a total of 8.5 acres of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Bela

texts.en:
Bela, 45 years old, is married and lives in Tskaltubo district with her husband and a daughter. Bela’s husband works at the local water supply company, where he earns a monthly salary. Bela's main income is her newly-started grocery store. It has been a profitable project, but it also needs more support to further develop. On several occasions, Bela has asked for loans from local financial institutions to develop her business, but has had no success. The loan requests were rejected because of her low income.

Bela’s loan request was approved as part of the new joint initiative through Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides business start-ups and re-startups with credit with soft conditions to the rural poor who do not have access to credit products, since they are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. With the received credit, Bela will cover the costs of purchasing needed basic grocery stock that customers often request. She will purchase stocks of detergent powders and sausages as these products are most in demand. Bela plans to increase her business turnover gradually. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly increase the family's income. Bela will work hard, and she will be able to improve her family's living conditions. With this loan, her family will generate enough income to access regular available credit products in the country’s capital market, should they need them.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of detergent powder and sausages for her grocery

loans.name: Nadutari

texts.en:
Nadutari has successfully paid off her second loan and her farming business is gradually but steadily growing. She is now farming on a bigger piece of her land and raises animals. She has applied for a third loan of KES 20,000 from KADET LTD, which she will use to buy a dairy cow.

She is determined to grow the business to higher levels as well as improve the family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy bales of clothes to add to her current stock

loans.name: Buloosi Group

texts.en:
Buloosi is a group of 10 farmers in Bungoma South District, and it is represented by Batista. The group has seven women and three men. Batista is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit, consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ an acre of maize, millet and sorghum. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Batista’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to access the best input prices and grow enough food for the family.


Last year, Batista harvested three bags of maize on one acre of land. She is excited to improve her harvest as a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and perhaps invest in another business. Batista’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ an acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total, they will receive inputs for five acres of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum

loans.name: Lumboka Humble Group

texts.en:
Moses is a member of Lumboka Humble Group in Bungoma South District. He is pictured with 10 One Acre Fund farmers, 4 women and 6 men. Moses is standing on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for ½ an acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Moses’ first season with One Acre Fund. He joined this year in order to access the best input prices and to grow enough food for the family.

Moses described his harvest last year as good, but hopes he can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and to save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit, for a group total of 5 acres worth of inputs.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a 23-year-old single man from Khanyounis. He is a very ambitious young man. He and his friend opened a small shop for selling mobile phones and accessories. This store has been operating for six years and is located in a good commercial area in Khanyounis, which makes the project a profitable one and the only source of income for him, but he needs more support to cover some costs.

Mohammad works very hard to improve his living conditions. He is requesting a USD Murabaha loan from FATEN to cover the cost of purchasing a new collection of mobile phones and accessories. This will increase sales and improve Mohammad's income positively. The photo shows Mohammad in his store.

About Shariah-compliant lending:

FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan. For more information on lending in the Muslim world, please visit Kiva's Muslim World Lending helptext: http://tinyurl.com/3aekx8m.

loans.use: To buy mobile phones and accessories to sell

loans.name: Sinoko Wake Up A Group

texts.en:
Sinoko Wake Up A Group is located in Bungoma South District. It is a group of seven women and five men, and it is led by Cyrus, who is pictured on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for ½ an acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Cyrus is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. He joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizer and access to the best input prices. 

Cyrus managed to harvest 12 bags of maize on one acre of land last year. As a One Acre Fund farmer, he hopes to harvest even more. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to send his children to school and repair his home. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Cyrus’ group members will take input loans of ½ an acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on six acres of land.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum

loans.name: Dénise

texts.fr: Dénise est une de 49 ans, célibataire mère de 3 enfants. Elle est secrétaire dans une petite structure de la place et fait en même temps l’élevage prêt de son domicile depuis 3 ans. Son activité fonctionne, mais la petitesse de son capital ne lui permet plus de satisfaire sa clientèle grandissante d'où la nécessité de ce crédit en ce moment pour son activité. grâce à lui, elle pourra augmenter les poussins ainsi que la provende pour leur nutrition. les bénéfices générés par ce crédit seront en partie réinvestis dans son activité pour l'agrandir et le reste lui permettra de subvenir aux besoins quotidiens de sa famille.
texts.en: Dénise is a 49-year old single mother of three. She works as a secretary in a small local  organization and, at the same time, raises livestock by her house. She has been doing this for three years. Her business stays afloat, but her small capital no longer allows her to meet the growing customer demand, which is why she needs a loan at this time. Thanks to this loan, she will able to increase the number of chicks and provide feed for them. Part of the revenues generated thanks to this loan will be reinvested in her business in order to grow it further, and the rest will allow her to provide for everyday household needs.

loans.use: to buy chicks and feed for them.

loans.name: Hazratkul

texts.ru: Хазраткул проживает в городе Худжанд. Ему 55 лет. Он женат. У него двое детей. Жена Хазраткула работает в колхозе. Хазраткул имеет среднее образование. Хазраткул вместе с сыном занимается животноводством. Он разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. Таким образом Хазраткул зарабатывает вот уже пятнадцать лет. Он берет кредит для закупа коров и телят с целью увеличения поголовья крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Hazratkul lives in the town of Khujand. He is 55 years and married. He has two children. Hazratkul’s wife works on a collective farm. Hazratkul has secondary education. Together with his son, Hazratkul  is engaged in animal husbandry. He raises cattle by his house. He has been making a living in this way for some 15 years. He is taking out a loan to buy cows and calves in order to increase his headcount.

loans.use: to buy cows and calves.

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Philomina is a petty trader who sells yams, vegetables such as tomatoes, onions, garden eggs, oil and other food items. Philomina has been in this business for 10 years now.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a farmer. She uses her income to assist her husband in paying their children’s school fees. Philomina will use her loan to purchase more vegetables to sell. With the new profit, she will expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: David

texts.en: David is a 45-year-old gentleman from the outskirts of Kyotera. He is married with a family and has six children. His main activity is growing bananas and coffee. In addition to this, David has a small retail shop that gives him a small income for his day-to-day expenses. He applied for a loan of 1,500,000 shillings to upgrade his banana plantation. David sells his produce to traders who come from the city of Kyotera and his neighbours who cannot produce their own food. He dreams of buying a bigger portion of land so that he can increase his production and satisfy his customers. However, he faces challenges of price fluctuations, poor storage facilities, poor means of transport and middlemen who buy his produce and refuse to pay him sometimes.

loans.use: To buy mulching materials and hire labour

loans.name: Safarali

texts.ru: Сафарали 43 года. Он проживает в районе Шахритус. У него большая семья - жена и пятеро детей. Сафарали несколько лет занимается земледелием. Сейчас он хочет начать новый бизнес и для этого выбрал сферу животноводства. Сегодня эта деятельность приносит хорошую прибыль. Для реализации своей цели Сафарали обратился за кредитом. Он берет кредит для закупа крупно-рогатого скота. После его откармливания Сафарали хочет продать скот на рынке с наценкой. За счет прибыли он планирует увеличить поголовье скота.
texts.en: Safarali is forty-three years old. He lives with his wife and five children in the Shahrituz region of Tajikistan. For several years now he has made a living by farming. Now he wants to expand his business to cattle breeding, which is very profitable these days. However, he needs some capital to purchase the initial batch of large-horned cattle. He plans to fatten this cattle and then sell it at the market for a profit. Safarali then plans to reinvest these profits and buy more cattle.

loans.use: to purchase large-horned cattle.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn lives with her husband and three children.  She sells provisions like rice, cooking oil, macaroni, caned tomatoes, caned fish and more, which she has done for 20 years.

She uses her income to support her husband and to maintain her home. 

Evelyn will use her loan to purchase various provisions in large quantities to satisfy her customers.  With the new profit Evelyn will expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase various provisions in large quantities

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 32 years old fruit vendor and fresh juice dealer in Changamwe Mombasa.  She is a married mother of three children.  Her husband provides extra income. 

She has been in business for the past three years and has done well with a great income.  Elizabeth is requesting her second loan to purchase more fruit needed to make juice and a cooler. 

Elizabeth will use the anticipated profits to expand her business.  She hopes to prosper in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit needed to make juice and a cooler.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 45 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in Uganda. She is widowed and has two children. For the past five years, Margaret has been working hard to manage her poultry business.  She rears chicken. 

To help expand her business, Margaret has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more birds to increase her business.  The loan will also help Margaret generate greater profits and save money.  Margaret hopes that in the future she will be able to supply quality chicken. 

Margaret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Margaret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.


"

loans.use: to buy more birds.

loans.name: Sabore Ole

texts.en:
Sabore is preparing for another planting season.  He plans to cultivate a larger piece of land to plant maize and wheat. 

He has acquired a loan of KES. 80,000 which will facilitate his land preparations and enable him to purchase farm inputs.  He has successfully repaid his first loan. 

Sabore hopes to grow his farming business in to a large scale venture and to educate his children to higher levels of learning.

loans.use: to prepare his land and buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Manana

texts.en:
Manana is a 57-year-old woman from the small town Tsavkisi, near capital city.  She is a widow and lives with her family: son, daughter–in-law, grandchild and retired mother. 

Manana works as a watchman at the local school and her son serves the local people as a driver.  Both earn a monthly income. 

Manana requested credit to start up a new business.  She will purchase construction materials and hire workers to renovate a greenhouse that is located in Manana’s yard.  She will purchase rose saplings and plant them in the greenhouse.  The picked flowers will be sold to local flower retailers. 

The loan will significantly increase her family’s income and help her family combat poverty and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to renovate the greenhouse and purchase rose saplings .

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 32 years old, married and blessed with two children that he supports.  He has run a retail shop for the last four years and earns a monthly income of KES. 20,000. 

With a loan of KES. 100,000 from KADET LTD he plans to restock his shop with a variety of products like maize flour, wheat flour, sugar and tea leaves for sale.

The anticipated profits will be plowed back to business for expansion.  Joseph's future dreams is to be successful in life

loans.use: to restock his shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy the tools, vacuum cleaner, and a hood for his car wash place.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is a married man with a family and has four children.   He applied for a loan of five million shillings but the branch loans committee only approved three million shillings. 

The purpose of this loan is to buy cows, fatten them and later sell them off to get money to back the loan.  Any balance will be used to build a house for his family and pay school fees for his siblings.

Robert's biggest challenge is access to enough capital.  In addition, he faces challenges related to cattle diseases, therefore he needs a lot of money to employ skilled personnel.

In addition to cattle keeping, Robert is engaged in crop cultivation; he grows bananas, maize for his family's consumption and the balance is sold off to earn some income. 

Robert is a calm, hardworking man, cooperative and ready to work.  This has been demonstrated by the passion for his job and good character.  He is in his third loan cycle.

loans.use: to buy cows.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine  is 45 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda.  She is widowed and has four children with one currently in school.  For the past seven years Catherine has worked hard to manage a boutique where she sells clothes . 

To help expand her business, Catherine has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to acquire more clothes, and will help Catherine generate greater profits and improve her business.  Catherine hopes that in the future she will be able to add to the business . 

Catherine  is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Catherine  who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.


"

loans.use: to acquire more clothes.

loans.name: Islam

texts.en:
Islam is 21 years old from Gaza.  

She asked Ryada for a loan to start her own center for tutoring school children.  She needs to buy used furniture, an electricity generator and air conditioner.

Islam hopes that this loan will help her build a career and improve her income.

Ryada's Startup Loan is exclusively for borrowers who are beginning new enterprises, not for existing projects.  To qualify, a borrower must show a clear business plan and realistic potential for success.  The borrower must also invest their own money and resources; at least 50 percent of the start up enterprise.  Ryada believes strongly in the potential of these borrowers and grants them a three month grace period to help them get their business off the ground.

loans.use: to buy used furniture, an electricity generator and air conditioner.

loans.name: Ufundi Group

texts.fr: La cliente Nzigire est leader du groupe de crédit Ufundi à 39 ans. Mariée à un commerçant est mère de 8enfants tous scolarisés. Elle avait pu débuter son activité grâce aux fonds reçu de son beau père avant de regagner son groupe de crédit dans lequel elle vient de réaliser plus de 5ans. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui permettre de s’approvisionner avec 25 chèvres qu'elle revendra en détail. Elle souhaite voir son entreprise grandir afin d'assurer une bonne survie à sa famille. Ainsi, elle remercie Hekima et son personnel qui lui facile l’accès au credit.
texts.en:
The borrower, Nzigire, is the leader of the "Ufundi" credit group.  She is 39 years old and the mother of eight children who all go to school.  Her husband is involved in commerce.

Nzigire was able to start her own business thanks to funds received from her father-in-law.  Later on, she joined the Ufundi credit group, of which she has been a member for more than five years.

With this new loan, she intends to buy 25 goats, for future retail resale.  Nzigire wishes to see her business grow, which will help her to take proper care of her family.  She thanks Hekima and its employees for facilitating access to credit.

loans.use: to buy 25 goats.

loans.name: Erisa

texts.en:
Erisa is 47 years old and lives in the town of Iganga in the Iganga region of Uganda. He is married and has three children. For the past five years, Erisa has been working hard to manage his retail business, which sells sugar, flour, rice and other items. 

To help expand his business, Erisa has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to add more commodities such as milk, splash juice and soap to increase business, and will help Erisa to generate greater profits and live a more comfortable life. Erisa hopes that in the future, he will be able to develop and grow a big business. 

Erisa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Erisa who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to add more commodities such as milk,splash juice and soap to increase business.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
The client started his business in 1988 and has been relying on it to support his family's needs ever since.
Later he found out that the business alone could not meet all the family's needs. He decided to join UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) – Rukungiri branch to receive financial assistance in increasing his business output in order to cater to the family's other needs especially school fees for his children.
In 2012, the client received a loan for school fees instead of using money from his business. This helped him to continue operating his business normally without any interruptions. The loan that he has taken now will be used to buy more items to restock his retail shop as it's now almost time for school to start again.
Stephen thanks UGAFODE Microfinance Limited (MDI) for the support he's been given which has helped both his business and his household.

loans.use: To buy items to restock his retail shop

loans.name: Samtry Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is very pleased to present to you members of the “Samtry” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to seek a loan of 500,000 SLL (Sierra Leone leones) for each in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Hawanatu is the leader of this group. Hawanatu is 38 years old. She is married with four children – two in primary school, one in secondary school and one not yet of school-going age. Hawanatu sells market food – palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), Margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), onions, pepper, etc. She has been doing business for six years now. With her share of this loan, she is going to buy the above-mentioned items in large quantities to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy palm oil, Margi, onions, pepper, etc., in large quantities to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Sabentee Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Sabentee” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Lunsar, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of 3,300,000 SLL (Sierra Leone leones) for the entire group in order to expand the size and qualities of their respective businesses. 

The featured leader of this group is Aminata. Aminata is age 55; she is married and has nine children. Her children are attending primary, secondary and tertiary educational institutions. Aminata has been a businesswoman for six years now. She sells market food – palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil), onions, Margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), pepper, tomatoes, salt, etc. With her share of this loan, she is going to buy the above-mentioned items in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, Margi, pepper, tomatoes, salt, etc., in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Hong's Group

texts.en: A widow with six children, Hong is 62 years old and a villager from Battambang Province’s Ek Phnom. The only source of income for her family is rice cultivation, from which she is able to earn up to 22,500 KHR per day. This is the business that she has been doing for 20 years. Hong, a loyal client who has been with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) for the past seven cycles, has fully repaid her loans with success and feels empowered that she can relieve her family's financial burden and make a good living. Furthermore, the past loan has returned her a decent income in order to fix her house as well as do the crop husbandry. This cycle, she is an eight-time borrower and her co-borrower is a six-time borrower. The total amount of their requested loan is 2,400,000 KHR. Hong, whose loan portion is 1,400,000 KHR, will spend her loan to purchase fertilizer. She highly hopes that this purchase will help her to boost her crop productivity and gain back a high yield.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Sdoeurng's Group

texts.en: Sdoeurng is 42-year-old single lady who lives in the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province. She survives her daily cost of living through rice cropping, watermelon growing, and fish catching, which she has been doing for 10 years. Now, she is in need of some working capital for supporting her crop husbandry. Hence, she formed a group of two as first-time borrowers to apply for a micro loan in amount of 1,000,000 KHR each with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. For Sdoeurng as a group leader, she is going to use her loan portion to buy fertilizer, insecticide and seeds and to pay the plowing fee for her farmland. She hopes this loan will help her business promptly and return her a good yield so that she can double her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, and seeds and to pay the plowing fee

loans.name: Phally's Group

texts.en: A 51-year-old mother of eight children, four of whom are still in school, Phally is married and a local farmer from a rural area located in the Ek Phnom district of Battambang Province. To earn additional income, she also leases tailoring machines. Her husband helps to make more income through buying pepper for resale. She has been involved in this business for 30 years. Phally joined VisionFund this cycle as a second loan cycle client with another first-time borrower in the same group of two female members. Her original loan has helped her to upgrade her lifestyle at a good pace. Now, she is seeking 1,200,000 KHR while her fellow group member is seeking 1,000,000 KHR. As a leader, she is going to spend her portion to buy two tailoring machine for her leasing-business. She hopes to make more income from her current business so that she can improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy two tailoring machines

loans.name: Sreytouch's Group

texts.en: A diligent farmer from Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Sreytouch is a 22-year-old married mother of two children. To earn a daily living, she grows beans and rice as the main source of income. Besides working on her rice farm, her husband catches fish for more income. She has been engaged in this business for six years. For her, the main challenge is the pest that destroyed her crop output. To tackle this problem, she formed a group of two to apply for a new loan of 1,000,000 KHR each. Sreytouch, a fourth-time borrower, formed a group with first-time borrower in order to apply for a new loan with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. She is satisfied with the result of her past loan, as it has returned her a good yield with high income to maintain her household. Now, she and her fellow group member are seeking 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilize, insecticide, and seeds for her farmland. She hopes to make more income from her business to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, and seeds

loans.name: Sivouch's Group

texts.en: Sivouch, a mother of six children, is originally from the Prey Chor district of Kampong Cham Province. She is 48 years old and a rice farmer on one hectare of farmland, which she has been doing for 30 years. Her main challenge is the shortage of working capital for supporting her business. Therefore, she formed a group of four to seek a new loan. This is the fourth time that she has been with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. After the successful loan that she paid back fully, she feels confident that she can make a good living for her family. Now, the entire group loan is 4,600,000 KHR. Sivouch's loan portion is 1,400,000 KHR. She is going to spend it on fertilizer, rice seed, and gasoline for water pumping for her farmland. She hopes that this purchase will boost her productivity and make more income for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, rice seed, and gasoline

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Cheung Prey district

loans.name: Phalla's Group

texts.en: A rural villager located in Kampong Cham province’s Tbaung Khmum district, Phalla is 45 years old and a married father of three children. Phalla is a rice farmer and a pig-raiser who has been involved in these businesses for 18 years. He is able to earn up to 40,000 KHR per day. In his group of two, Phalla is the group leader. He and his co-borrower have been with VisionFund for at least two past loan cycles. Phalla has repaid his loan completely and he feels confident in keeping his current businesses in good shape. Now, he and his group member are seeking 1,200,000 KHR each. As the leader, he is going to use his portion to buy pig feed. He hopes to fatten his pig in a healthy condition so that he can sell it for a high price.

loans.use: to buy pig feed

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Sokheab's Group

texts.en:
Sokheab, a young local farmer from Sa Ang district of Kandal Province, is 25 years old and has one son. To support her household, she sells grocery items at the front yard of her house and does rice cropping. Her husband works as a secondary school teacher in the local area. For the five years that she has involved in this business, she is able to earn up to 16,700 KHR per day. 

In a group of three, Sokheab is on her fourth-loan cycle with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. Her past loans have, indeed, helped relieve her family's burden and improve their livelihood. Now, she and two joint members are seeking 1,000,000 KHR each. Sokheab is going to use her portion to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and gasoline for water pumping on her rice farm. Additionally, she also will use a portion of it to buy more grocery items for reselling. She hopes that she can sustain both businesses in a good manner, so she can multiply her income for her children.

loans.use: to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and gasoline for water pumping.

loans.name: Ky

texts.en:
Ky is a 53-year-old married mother residing in a rural village located in Moung Russey district of Battambang Province. Ky has six children, three of whom are schoolchildren. For her and her family, paddy rice farm and cornfield are the main source of her family income. It is the business that she has been with for 10 years. 

This is the second loan with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. The first loan, which she has wisely used to upgrade her living conditions, has been repaid with success already. Now, she is seeking 2,000,000 KHR. She is going to use this to pay for the harvest fee for her paddy rice and corn. She hopes to gain triple her income so that she can replant these crops, and make a good profit to can keep her three children in school until tertiary level.

loans.use: to pay the harvest fee for her paddy rice and corn.

loans.name: Vutha

texts.en:
Originally from the Sampov Meas district of Cambodia, Vutha is 32 years old and married. He has three children to cater to, as all of them are still young. To deal with the financial hardship, he grows rice with the support of his wife. During their spare time, the couple also works for others for a fee for extra income.

Vutha's current income is 21,800 KHR per day. This is the first loan for Vutha with Kiva Field Partner, VisionFund. This loan cycle, he is seeking 2,000,000 KHR. He is going to spend his entire portion on his rice farm, purchasing four sacks of fertilizer and paying the leasing fee of a mini-tractor, plus the harvesting fee.

Vutha hopes to gain more crop yield so that he can run a small grocery stall for additional income.

loans.use: to buy four sacks of fertilizer.

loans.name: Chaan's Group

texts.en: Chaan, a widowed mother of five children and 48 years old, is a local farmer originally from Moung Russey district of Cambodia. She has two and a half hectares for growing paddy rice and one and a half hectares of farmland for growing sesame. Her daily income is about 23,000 KHR from the business that she has been with for 10 years, to cover the daily basic needs of her family. Chaan has been with VisionFund four times including this cycle. The past loans have provided her with working capital for supporting her business and improving her livelihood. Now, she has joined a group consisting of three female members. As the leader, she will spend her portion to pay harvesting fees and to buy fertilizer plus seeds for her farmland. She does believe that this prompt loan will keep a good growth of her business and provide her with triple productivity.

loans.use: To pay harvesting fees and to buy fertilizer plus seeds

loans.name: Saran's Group

texts.en:
Saran is the leader of Saran's Group. A rural villager from Battambang Province’s Moung Russey district, Saran is 44 years old and married. She has five children whom she needs to support since they are still in school. To tackle the daily cost of living, she does crop husbandry (rice-farming) on 3.5 hectares of farmland. She has done this for 13 years and it has returned income of about KHR 26,300 per day.

Three loan cycles ago was her original loan with VisionFund Cambodia, Kiva’s partner. She has used her loans in a smart way, promptly supporting her business and obtaining a better standard of living. 

Now, Saran and her co-borrower have formed a group of two (Saran's Group), to apply for a new loan from VisionFund Cambodia since they are in need of working capital for their businesses. Each of them is seeking a loan of KHR 1,400,000 (collectively, KHR 2,800,000). 

As the leader, Saran is going to use her portion to pay for labor that helps her harvest her rice paddy. She expects to gain more profit from her business, so she can increase her income for the sake of her children’s education.

loans.use: to pay for labor that will assist her in harvesting her rice crop.

loans.name: Samet's Group

texts.en:
Age 42 and a mother of five schoolchildren in the local public school, Samet is married and overcoming the family hardship through rice cropping on seven hectare of farmland. She has been involved in this business for fifteen years and earns up to 31,700 KHR per day. In a group of four female members, Samet and one of her co-borrowers are fourth-time borrowers, while the remaining two are third-time borrowers with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner for this cycle. 

Samet has smartly used her loan, which she repaid back with success, to support her business promptly and relieve her family’s burden. Specifically, she is able to earn a decent income to cover the daily basic needs of the family and keep her children in school. The total amount of this group cycle is 5,500,000 KHR.  Samet, whose loan portion is 1,400,000 KHR, will use her portion to pay for the harvesting fee. She highly hopes that this loan will support her to gain high yield and earn a good profit so that she can keep supporting her children’s education.

loans.use: To pay for the harvesting fee

loans.name: Sal's Group

texts.en: Sal, a mother of three schoolchildren, is 35 years old. She resides in the Moung Russey district of Battambang Province, Cambodia. She makes a living via rice cultivation, which she has been involved with for 10 years. This is the third loan cycle for Sal with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. She has used the funds from her past loan, which she has fully paid back with success to keep up the good progress of her business as well as her living conditions. Now, she is in a group of two. She and her co-borrower are seeking loans of 1,400,000 KHR and 1,200,000 KHR, respectively. As a leader, she is going to use her portion to pay for the harvesting fees of her crop husbandry. She greatly hopes that she will gain a double crop output in order to sustain her current living conditions and increase her income.

loans.use: To pay for harvesting fees

loans.name: Sophea's Group

texts.en: Sophea, a diligent farmer in a village located in the Moung Russey district of Battambang Province, is a young 27-year-old mother of two children; one is in school and one is too young to attend school. Her main sources of income are from bean growing on one and half hectares of farmland and grocery selling in the front yard of her house. The business that she has been with for 7 years has returned about 31,000 KHR per day. This cycle is the second-cycle loan for Sophea. The first loan that she has fully paid back with success has helped her to improve her living condition gradually. Now, she has formed a group of three to apply for a new loan. She is seeking 1,200,000 KHR, while the other two group members are the first-time borrowers seeking 1,000,000 KHR each. As the leader, Sophea is going to use her portion to buy more items to replenish her grocery selling business, including soap, instant noodle, canned food, and other food items. With the rest of her loan, she is going to buy seed and to pay the plowing fee for her bean farm. She hopes that this purchase will support the needs of her business in a timely manner and increase her income so that she can keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy seed and to pay the plowing fee.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Sophal is a 40-year-old widowed mother living under a thatched roof house with four children.

She has overcome the family’s financial hardships as a single mother through rice cultivation on one hectare of farmland. She is able to earn up to 20,800 KHR per day from the business, which she has been in for 22 years.

The main challenge for Sophal is the flood which has lowered her crop production. To overcome this challenge, she is applying for a new loan. She is going to spend her entire loan amount on purchasing potash for her rice. She hopes that this purchase will allow her to recover her losses and boost her crop output so that she can gain triple the income.

loans.use: To buy potash for her rice.

loans.name: Phea's Group

texts.en:
Phea is the leader of Phea's Group. Originally from Battambang Province’s Moung Russey district, Phea is married and 42 years old. She has four children. Two children still count on her since they are still in school and two are living independently. 

For ten years, Phea has farmed rice on three hectares of land and grown sesame on two hectares. She is able to earn up to KHR 17,800 per day. Her husband also helps to make more income by working for others for a fee during his spare time. 

In a group of four (Phea's Group), Phea is the leader. She is a fourth-time borrower who has completely repaid her past loans with success. The loans have unloaded her family’s burden and gradually improved its livelihood. 

Phea and one of her co-borrowers are each seeking KHR 1,400,000, while the remaining two members are each applying for KHR 1,200,000. Phea is going to spend her portion of the loan on harvesting fees, potash, and seed purchasing. She hopes to produce a better crop yield and increase her income, so that she can keep her children in school up to higher education.

loans.use: to pay for harvesting fees, potash, and seed purchasing.

loans.name: Thy's Group

texts.en:
A father of two kids originally from Kror Kor district of Pursat Province, Thy is 47 years old and married.

Rice crops are the main source of income for his family to cover their daily expenses. He has been involved in this business for 22 years and is able to earn about 15,000 KHR per day.

Now, the harvest season is coming. Hence, he formed a group of three members to apply for a new loan. This is Thy's second cycle with Kiva Field Partner, VisionFund. The past loan, which he has completely paid back, has strengthened his confidence by uplifting his lifestyle in a good way.

For the new loan cycle, Thy is seeking 1,200,000 KHR, while his two fellow group members are applying for 1,000,000 KHR each. He hopes that requesting this loan, which he will use to pay harvesting fees, will promptly support his business so that he can gain double yield with good profits for his children’s sake.

loans.use: To pay harvesting fees.

loans.name: Chroeb's Group

texts.en:
Chroeb is a 45-year-old mother of seven children, four of whom are still in school.

For the livelihood of her big household, she grows rice and her husband supplements the family’s income by catching fish for resale. For 25 years she has been involved in this business, and she is able to earn up to 10,200 KHR per day.

Chroeb's prior loan was an original loan with Kiva Field Partner, VisionFund. She has smartly used it to sustain her business and progressively improve her living conditions.

Now, she is the leader in a micro-loan group consisting of two female members who are second-time borrowers. Chroeb will use her portion to pay plowing fees plus water-pumping fees, and to purchase fertilizer for her farmland for the upcoming replanting season. She hopes that she will be able to make more income, thereby enabling her four children to pursue their studies until the post-secondary level.

loans.use: to pay plowing and water-pumping fees.

loans.name: Sreynuon's Group

texts.en: Sreynuon is 33 years old and married. She has three children: two of them are still in school while the remaining one is still too young for schooling. The rest of her family lives in a local village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang Province. Like a lot of people in her neighborhood, she is also a rice farmer. To earn extra income, her husband works for others for a fee during his spare time. He has been involved in this business for 7 years and is able to earn up to 32,800 KHR per day. Sreynuon has been with VisionFund for three loan cycles. She has wisely used her loans to better support her business. She uses her increased income for her household’s daily expenses. Now, she needs some working capital to pay for the harvesting fees of her paddy rice. Hence, she formed a group of three to seek out a new loan. She hopes that this loan will support her business in a timely manner and bring her multiple crop yields so that she can earn more income to not only support her entire household’s expenses but also keep her children in school.

loans.use: To pay for harvesting fees

loans.name: Houch

texts.en:
A citizen from a rural area located in the Bakan district where rice farming is a common way to earn a living, Houch is aged 31 years and married. She has five children, all of whom are dependent on her and still in school. She and her husband have struggled to feed their children by farming rice and weaving brooms while her husband works for others for a fee to earn additional income for the family. 

Houch can earn about US$5 per day and manages to save about US$1.50 each day after deducting daily expenses. Insufficient water supply is the main challenge for her paddy rice business. 

Houch has been with VisionFund for one cycle and completely paid back the past loan which has helped her better support her family with enough foods. Now she is applying for another loan of US$625 to buy a buffalo to help her in her farming business. Houch hopes to get a high yield from her paddy so as to better her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo to help her in her farming business

loans.name: Pov's Group

texts.en: Residing in a local village from Battambang Province’s Moung Russey district, Pov is married and has four children. He and his wife provide for the rest of their family, especially their children, through growing paddy rice and sesame. He is able to earn up to 18,900 KHR per day from his current business that he has been with for 15 years. In a group of two, Pov is a fourth loan cycle client, and his co-borrower is a fifth loan cycle client with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. The past three loans, which he has fully paid back, have provided a sufficient capital for continuing the sustainability of his crop husbandry. Now, he and his group member are seeking loans in the amount of 1,400,000 KHR each to support their businesses. Pov is going to use his portion to pay for his harvesting fees. He does believe that he will gain a good yield again and increase his income for his family’s sake.

loans.use: To pay for harvesting fees

loans.name: Yern's Group

texts.en:
Yern, 44 years old, is a villager residing in a rural area of Ek Phnom district in Battambang province, Cambodia. She is a widow and also a mother of two dependent children, both of whom are students. 

This hard-working, single mother works many jobs to earn a living for the family. She farms rice, raises chickens, and works for others as a paid worker. Each day, she is able to earn around KHR 28,000 and save approximately KHR 8,000, after offsetting the daily cost of living. 

This will be Yern’s fourth time requesting a loan via VisionFund Cambodia (Kiva’s partner). Yern succeeded in making the family’s lifestyle better with the help of the previous loans. Now she is leading Yern's Group, a loan group of three female members, to take out a loan in the cumulative amount of KHR 2,500,000. 

As a group representative, Yern will spend her loan portion on purchasing fertilizer and rice seed to support her rice field. With the help of this new, requested loan, Yern believes that her rice-growing business will provide her with a good quality crop yield, so that she can earn more income for the family and use the anticipated income to support her children’s education.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and rice seed for her rice field.

loans.name: Mok's Group

texts.en: Mok is a rural villager from the Moung Russey district of Battambang Province. He has three children to care for; one is a schoolboy, and the other two are too young for school. To support the entire household, he and his wife grow paddy rice on two hectares and sesame on one hectare of farmland. This is the business that he has been in for ten years, and he is able to earn up to 19,700 KHR per day. This is his third loan cycle with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. The past loans, which he has repaid, have changed his living conditions at a good pace and improved his family’s livelihood. Now he is in need of working capital for his business. He has formed a group of three borrowers to apply for a new loan. He and one of his co-borrowers are seeking 1,200,000 KHR each, while the other group member is seeking 1,000,000 KHR. He is going to spend his loan portion, as the leader, to pay harvesting fees and buy rice seed and fertilizer to replant his paddy for the upcoming season. He keenly hopes that he can have sufficient capital to pay the labor costs to harvest on time and increase his yield, so he can double his income and improve his lifestyle.

loans.use: to pay harvesting fees and buy rice seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Thim's Group

texts.en: Thim is 31 years old, married, and has two children. One of them is in school, and the other is too young for school. Thim has struggled to deal with her living costs by growing rice with the support of her husband. She has been in this business for eight years and is able to earn up to 23,300 KHR per day. Thim has been with VisionFund for two loan cycles and has successfully repaid her loans. The loans have helped her a great deal by supporting her business and empowering her gradually to improve her life style. For this cycle, she is in a group with four members. Three borrowers, including Thim, are their third borrowing cycle, while the remaining member is a second-cycle client, with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. Each of them is seeking the same loan amount of 1,000,000 KHR. As the group leader, Thim is going to spend her portion on harvesting fees for her crop. She hopes that this working capital will support her through the season, so that she can earn more income and keep her children in school.

loans.use: to pay for harvesting fees.

loans.name: Encarnación

texts.es: La señora Encarnación es madre soltera y trabaja de manera independiente desde hace varios años. La Sra. Encarnación  tiene una venta de barrio en la cual dedica el mayor tiempo posible en mantenerlo surtido  para el agrado de sus clientes , la señora todos los días  inicia la jornada desde las 5:30am hora en que  va  comprar  carne y pollo para su venta, tiene el apoyo de su hija   la cual aun depende de ella porque está estudiando, su aporte de su hija es significativo ya que solamente las dos atienden la venta. La señora Encarnación, en gestiones pasadas solicito un crédito el cual pago de manera puntual demostrando ser cumplida con sus obligaciones, el préstamo es en favor de su negocio para lo cual necesita comprar más insumos para su negocio y así poder brindar un buen servicio a sus clientes. Ella demostró ser eficaz en su negocio y cumplida con sus obligaciones.
texts.en:
Señora Encarnación is a single mother and has worked independently for several years.  She has a neighborhood store in which she spends as much time as possible keeping it stocked up to the liking of her customers.  Every day she starts her workday at 5:30 in the morning to go buy meat and chicken for her sales.  She has the help of her daughter who still depends on her because she is in school.  The contribution of her daughter is significant because only the two of them take care of sales.  

Señora Encarnación, in past efforts, asked for a loan which she payed off in a timely manner, demonstrating that she can fulfill her obligations.  The loan is in favor of her business, for which she needs to buy more supplies and thus be able to offer better service to her customers.  She has shown herself to be efficient in her business and fulfilling in her obligations.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Ngov's Group

texts.en: A local farmer residing in Moung Russey district of Battambang Province, Ngov is the father of three children who are dependent on him, as two of them are in school and one is still too young for school. To pay their daily costs for food and other necessities, he has been growing rice and planting chili for several years. The business currently earns him about 15,600 KHR per day, to spend on his family. In a group of two, Ngov and his fellow group member are in their fourth loan cycle with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner. Ngov has fully paid back his previous loans, and they have helped him steadily to upgrade his living conditions. Now, he and his co-group member are seeking 1,400,000 KHR each. Ngov, the leader, is going to use his portion of the loan to pay for harvesting fees. He is confident that he will earn more income, so that he can keep up a good pace of improvement of his life style and keep all of his children in school.

loans.use: to pay for harvesting fees.

loans.name: Vanly

texts.en:
Vanly is aged 30 years old and married. She lives with her husband and three children in a rural area located in the Ek Phnom District, Cambodia. 

Vanly has been selling rice for several years, and her husband also supplements the income by working as a motor taxi driver in the local area. The current business earns her family about 50,000 KHR per day to feed the family, but Vanly manages to save about 20,000 KHR each day.

This is the first loan for Vanly with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. Now requesting a loan of US $400, she is going to use this loan to build a market stall for her rice-selling business. Through this loan, she hopes to earn more income from her current business.

loans.use: to build a market stall for her rice-selling business.

loans.name: Lem's Group

texts.en: Lem, a local farmer from Moung Russey district of Battambang Province, is 54 years old and has nine children. Three children who are still in school are dependent on her. Lem has one and a half hectares of farmland for growing paddy rice and one hectare for growing beans. To supplement the family’s income, her husband also works for others for a fee, besides helping on her farm. She has engaged in this business for ten years and is able to earn up to 26,000 KHR per day. This is not Lem's first loan, as she has been with VisionFund, Kiva’s partner for two earlier loan cycles. After successfully paying back her last loan, she feels empowered to sustain a good standard of living for her family. Now she is the leader of a group of two. Both of them are in the same cycle and requesting the same loan amount of 1,200,000 KHR each. Lem’s portion is going to spend part of her portion on harvesting fees and another part to buy fertilizer, seed, and insecticide. She expects to receive a good yield so that she can earn more income to maintain her good living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for harvesting fees and buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Senghak's Group

texts.en: Residing in a rural village of Battambang province’s Ek Phnom district in Cambodia, Senghak is 27 years of age and married. She has a son and a daughter, both of whom are her responsibility. One of her children is currently a student while the other one stays home to assist in the family’s businesses, which are rice-growing and bean-planting. To support the family, Senghak farms rice and plants bean while her husband catches fish and works for others as a paid worker to supplement the income. Together, this couple can earn around 30,000 KHR per day and save about 10,000 KHR after the daily expenses. Senghak, a fourth-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner), is leading a member who is a third-time borrower to apply for a loan in the amount of 1,400,000 KHR each. With the previous loans, the group leader Senghak was able to improve the family’s lifestyle. This time, she will use the requested loan portion to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and bean seeds to support her current businesses. This hard-working woman (Senghak) believes that she will be able to improve her family’s living conditions even better after receiving her portion of the loan and using it in a smart manner. She is also willing to use the income generated by the current businesses to send all her kids to school and fully support their education.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and bean seeds.

loans.name: Savat's Group

texts.en:
Originally from a village of the Ek Phnom District where rice farming is a common way to make a living, Savat is a 42-year-old mother of four children who are still in school. 

To make a living, she has been involved in rice farming and grocery selling for 12 years, while her husband also complements the income by raising pigs and cows. A low crop resulting from flooding is the main challenge for her plantation business. 

Savat has been with VisionFund for one cycle and completely paid back the past loan, while the other group member is just with VisionFund this cycle. Now Savat is leading her group of two to seek another loan. 

As the leader, Savat is going to use her portion to buy fertilizer and pesticide for her plantation and use a portion of it to buy pig feed for her pig-raising. She hopes to grow her rice healthfully and fruitfully so as to make a better living and keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide for her plantation.

loans.name: Phearom's Group

texts.en:
Phearom is 28 years old and a resident of a rural village of Ek Phnom District, located in Cambodia’s Battambang Province. 

She is single and earns a living through farming rice, growing cucumbers and catching fish. Having been in the current businesses for eight years, Phearom is able to earn approximately 30,000 KHR per day and manages to save 10,000 KHR after canceling out the daily expenses. 

Phearom is a fourth-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She was able to improve her living standard via the help of the previous loans that she successfully paid back. Now she is leading a loan group of three female members to apply for a loan in the amount of 3,800,000 KHR in total. 

The group representative, Phearom, will spend her loan portion on supporting her businesses by purchasing fertilizer, cucumber seeds, and fishing materials such as fish traps and cast nets. 

Phearom expects a boost in her income after receiving and wisely using her requested loan portion.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, cucumber seeds, and fishing materials.

loans.name: Anny

texts.es:
La  señorita Anny,  tiene 22 años de edad, vive en su casa de habitación en una colonia de San Lorenzo, en la zona sur de Honduras, se dedica desde hace 4  años a la venta de ropa juvenil, ropa de niño, camisas, zapatos, perfumes, maquillajes, cremas, etc. 
Anny su negocio está ubicado en su casa y también sale a vender a los bancos y casa comerciales de la zona, sus clientes son los vecinos y amigos que visita para ofrecerles sus productos.
Anny está solicitando el préstamo para compra de camisas, pantalones, vestidos, calzonetas, perfumes, cremas, zapatos y maquillajes, para tener más productos que ofrecer a sus clientes y aprovechar la temporada navideña que las personas compran bastante este tipo de productos ya que esta temporada el comercio en su negocio aumenta.
Anny su sueño es ampliar mas su negocio y tener más productos que ofrecer.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Noviembre  del 2012.
texts.en:
Anny is 22 years old, she lives in her own house in one of the San Lorenzo communities, in the south of Honduras. She has been in retail for 4 years, selling youth clothing, children’s clothes, shirts, shoes, perfumes, make-up, and lotions among other items. Her business is located in her house, but she also goes to stalls and shops to sell her products. Her customers are her friend and her neighbors, whom she visits to offer them her products.
Anny is requesting a loan of 15,000.00 lempiras to buy shirts, skirts, trousers, suits, shoes, perfumes, and cosmetics in order to have a wide variety of products to offer to all of her customers.
Anny wants to buy at wholesale price to get ready for the Christmas season, as this is the time when she sells the most. She dreams of expanding her business and offering more products to her costumers.


San Lorenzo, Honduras – November 2012.

loans.use: To buy shirts, skirts, trousers, suits, shirts and sweaters.

loans.name: Lekhena's Group

texts.en:
Living in a rural village in the Bakan district of Cambodia, Lekhena is 33 years old and married with three children, all of whom are still in school. The family’s main source of income is that Lekhena and her husband both are wage laborers for others in their village.

Lekhena has been with VisionFund, Kiva's field partner, for three loan cycles, successfully using her past loans to provide more food for her family. Now she is leading a loan group of three members, who have been with VisionFund ranging from one to three loan cycles. As the group leader, Lekhena is going to use her portion to buy a proper bike for commuting to work. She hopes this loan will enable her to earn more income than she currently does.

loans.use: to buy a proper bike for commuting to work

loans.name: Sina's Group

texts.en:
Sina, age 51, is a rural villager from the Bakan district. She has made a living through farming rice and weaving broom. Having been in this business for thirty years, she is able to earn about 14,000 KHR per day and manages to save about 4,000 KHR each day after daily expenses. She and her husband have three children, one of whom is dependent on her and still in school.
 
This is the fourth loan for Sina with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. She has fully repaid her previous loans, which have helped her to relieve her family’s burden and improve her livelihood. She is the leader of this group of two, and each of the group members is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 KHR. Sina will use her portion to buy piglets to raise in order to earn additional income for her family. 

She is confident that this loan will enable her to sufficiently fatten her pigs so that she can eventually sell them for a good price and improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy piglets to raise and eventually sell

loans.name: Rosa Ramona

texts.es:
La señora Rosa, vive en la ciudad de Tegucigalpa,  es soltera y no tiene hijos, vive con su hermana. Hace un año que una amiga le enseño a elaborar aretes, collares, pulseras y anillos, por lo que ahora se dedica a este negocio.
Doña Rosa cuenta con clientes fijas como sus compañeras de trabajo y vecinas de su colonia, también vende tajaditas de plátano, yuca y otros, en sus tiempos libres los fines de semana se dedica  a la costura, siendo una persona muy trabajadora y responsable con muchas ganas de salir adelante.
Doña Rosa está solicitando el préstamo para la compra de broches, aretes, terminales, argollas, alicates, pintura, cielo falso estas dos últimas son para realizar unas mejoras a su vivienda como pintarla y cambio de cielo falso.
Doña Rosa  tiene varios pedidos para la temporada navideña y con el préstamo espera invertir mas en su negocio y obtener ganancias que le permitan mejorar un poco su calidad de vida y la de su familia.



Tegucigalpa, Honduras - Noviembre del 2012
texts.en:
Rosa lives in the city of Tegucigalpa. She is single and has no children. She lives with her sister. One year ago, a friend taught her how to make earrings, necklaces, bracelets, and rings, so now she works doing this. Rosa has regular customers, like her co-workers and neighbors from her community. She also sells dried slices of plantain and yucca, among those things. In her free time on the weekends, she works sewing, because she is a very hardworking and responsible person with a great desire to advance. She is applying for the loan to buy brooches, earrings, fastenings, rings, pliers, paint, and a drop ceiling. These last two things are for making improvements to her home, like painting it and changing the drop ceiling. Rosa has several orders for the Christmas season and with this loan, she hopes to invest more in her business and make an income that allows her to improve her quality of life and that of her family.

Tegucigalpa, Honduras - November 2012

loans.use: to buy brooches, earrings, fastenings, rings, pliers, paint, and a drop ceiling for her business and home.

loans.name: Rom's Group

texts.en:
Rom, 50, is from a rural village located in the Kror Kor district of Pursat province. She is widowed with four children, one of whom is still in school. She and her husband earn a living through farming rice. Engaging in this business for ten years, Rom is able to earn about 9,000 KHR per day and she can manage to save about 3,000 KHR each day after offsetting daily expenses. 

Rom has been with VisionFund for two cycles while the other members of her group have been with VisionFund from one to three cycles. Rom successfully paid back the past loans which have enabled her to support the family with sufficient food. Now she is leading her group of three to ask for a loan. Rom will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland and use a portion on buying household supplies. She hopes this loan will help her to get a high crop yield from her paddy-field so as to improve her standard of living and keep her child in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

loans.name: Zoraida

texts.es: LA SEÑORA ZORAIDA junto a su familia vive en su propio domicilio, es una persona de 41 años de edad, de estado civil casada, alcanzo a estudiar la primaria, cuenta con seis dependientes económicos a su cargo los cuales son sus hijos. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la producción agrícola, produce papa, haba, arveja y maíz en sus propios terrenos que se hallan situados en la comunidad de Thoqo Rancho del municipio de Tiraque distante a unos 73 Km. desde la ciudad de Cochabamba.  Asimismo su esposo trabaja prestando sus servicios de ayudante en la empresa AMVI (Asociación de Mantenimiento Vial) en la misma zona generando ingresos mensuales. Y finalmente la señora Zoraida junto a su esposo manifiestan ser personas trabajadores y responsables que quieren superarse e incrementar su producción agrícola y para tal efecto se ve en la necesidad de solicitar capital de reposición por la compra de terreno agrícola y de tal forma obtener mayores ingresos económicos que van a mejorar la calidad de vida de sus dependientes.
texts.en:
Zoraida lives with her family in her own home.  She is 41 years old, married, and has an elementary school education.  She has six dependents, her children, who are under her care.

Her business activity is agricultural production.  She grows potatoes, beans, peas, and corn on her own land.  The land is situated in the Thoqo Rancho community in the Tiraque municipality, which is 73 kilometers from the city of Cochabamba.  

Her husband works by providing his services as a helper in the AMVI (Road Maintenance Association) in the same area, and he generates monthly income.  Zoraida and her husband show themselves to be hard-working and responsible people who want to succeed and increase their agricultural production.

In order to do so, they see the necessity of requesting capital to buy agricultural land.  That way they will get greater income, and they will improve the quality of life for their dependents.

loans.use: to buy agricultural land.

loans.name: Oscar Romeo

texts.es:
El señor Oscar de 45  años de edad es casado, tiene tres hijos  que dependen  de él, sus hijos tienen edades de 08, 15 y 22 años, vive en una comunidad de San Lorenzo, al sur de Honduras, tiene casa propia  y se dedica desde hace 20  años  a la actividad de la construcción, el construye casas, edificios y todo lo relacionado a la albañilería.
Don Oscar es contratista y se desempeña en esta actividad en varios lugares su comunidad y fuera de ahí, sus clientes le prefieren por su buen trabajo y nitidez en sus proyectos.
Don Oscar está solicitando el préstamo para la  compra de ladrillos, arena, cemento, grava, varillas de  hierro  y piedras para construir un muro en la parte de atrás de su casa, el lo construirá en los, momentos libres que no trabaja, está muy contento de seguir trabajando con Prisma ya que su casa la ha mejorado gracias al apoyo de los préstamo que Prisma le ha otorgado, está solicitando su cuarto préstamo.
Don Oscar su sueño es seguir mejorando su casa.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Noviembre  del 2012.
texts.en:
Oscar is 45 years old, married and has three children, ages 8, 15, and 22.  He lives in a home of his own located in San Lorenzo, in the south of Honduras and has been doing construction work for 20 years.  He builds houses, buildings, and anything involving masonry.
